input:
Research and write an enterprise-grade, full-length sales proposal for SIG (Susquehanna Investment Group / Susquehanna International Group) to adopt Hebbia, with a primary emphasis on strategic growth opportunities, operating leverage, and measurable efficiency gains. This must be a thorough, data-backed, boardroom-quality proposal with both quantitative and qualitative research, suitable for an enterprise purchase decision.

0) Operating constraints
	•	Treat this as a formal enterprise sales proposal: rigorous, specific, citation-driven, conservative in claims.
	•	Do not imply SIG is a customer of Hebbia or that SIG endorsed anything.
	•	Use only verifiable sources for factual claims; add citations for all statistics, product claims, security claims, market claims, and SIG facts.
	•	If a fact cannot be verified, either omit it or label it clearly as an assumption.
	•	Maintain enterprise tone: precise, minimal hype, measurable outcomes.

1) Research objectives (growth + efficiency first)

Build a complete research dossier and proposal anchored on three pillars:

Pillar A — Strategic growth enablement (capacity creation)

Identify where Hebbia increases SIG’s ability to:
	•	evaluate more opportunities and scenarios per unit time
	•	expand coverage across markets, instruments, regimes, and counterparties
	•	respond faster to new information with decision-ready conviction
	•	scale high-quality outputs (briefs, memos, reviews) without linear headcount growth

Pillar B — Operational efficiencies (cost-out + cycle-time compression)

Quantify and document how Hebbia reduces:
	•	time-to-conviction and decision cycle time
	•	duplicated diligence and rework
	•	coordination overhead and time spent assembling context
	•	document review effort and variance in outputs

Pillar C — Growth value proposition (quality + defensibility that unlocks speed)

Show how Hebbia improves:
	•	decision quality through traceable reasoning and citations
	•	governance through auditability, security, and controlled deployment
	•	institutional memory and reuse (compounding intelligence)

2) Required research scope

A) SIG research (must cite)

Collect from credible sources:
	•	SIG official sites, affiliated pages, and public descriptions of business lines
	•	SIG job postings across trading, quant research, risk, legal/compliance, ops (to infer workflows, tools, pain points)
	•	credible press/interviews/profiles that describe SIG’s operating model, scale, and market activity

B) Hebbia research (must cite)

Use Hebbia primary sources:
	•	Product pages and docs for Matrix / Agents / Draft
	•	Security posture and deployment claims
	•	Blog posts and case studies relevant to finance and high-stakes reasoning
Also use reputable third-party coverage to validate framing.

C) Competitive alternatives (must cite)

Compare against:
	•	generic LLM chat interfaces
	•	RAG/search platforms
	•	knowledge management systems
	•	internal build (“build vs buy” analysis)

3) Required research methods (must use all)

Method 1 — Quantitative modeling (efficiency + growth)

Build models that translate workflow improvements into growth capacity and operating leverage:
	1.	Time-to-conviction model (baseline vs. Hebbia) by workflow type
	2.	Decision throughput model (capacity creation): “how many more analyses/memos/reviews per week”
	3.	Operational efficiency model: labor hours reduced, rework rate reduced, cycle time reduced
	4.	Risk-cost proxy model (secondary): avoidable misses due to precedent/document oversight
	5.	ROI model with low/base/high cases + sensitivity analysis (headcount, volume, time saved, adoption)

Method 2 — Qualitative synthesis (growth narrative)

Produce:
	•	SIG buyer persona map (trading leadership, quant research leadership, risk, legal/compliance, platform/data)
	•	Objections + responses focused on adoption, governance, and “time to value”
	•	“Why now” narrative grounded in credible enterprise adoption trends (with citations)

Method 3 — Use-case underwriting (10–15 deep use cases)

For each use case include:
	•	business objective tied to growth or efficiency
	•	stakeholders / owners
	•	inputs (document types, systems)
	•	workflow steps
	•	outputs and “definition of done”
	•	why Hebbia (Matrix vs Agents vs Draft mapping)
	•	measurable KPIs (cycle time, throughput, reuse, quality)
	•	adoption notes and rollout risks

4) Proposal deliverable requirements (structure + length)

Deliver a long, thorough proposal with the following sections (use these exact headers):
	1.	Cover & Disclaimer
	2.	Executive Summary (Growth + Operating Leverage)
	3.	SIG Strategic Context (Where Growth Is Constrained)
	4.	Problem Statement: Decision Latency as Opportunity Cost
	5.	Value Thesis: Operating Leverage from Enterprise Reasoning
	6.	Hebbia Overview
	7.	Product Deep Dive (Matrix, Agents, Draft)
	8.	Security, Governance, and Auditability
	9.	SIG Growth & Efficiency Use Case Portfolio (10–15 Use Cases)
	10.	Quantified Value Hypothesis (Capacity Created + Cost Reduced)
	11.	Pilot Plan (6–8 weeks)
	12.	Rollout & Change Management Plan (90/180/365 days)
	13.	Integration and Data Strategy
	14.	ROI Model + Sensitivity Analysis
	15.	Competitive Alternatives + Build vs Buy
	16.	Risks, Mitigations, and Controls
	17.	Procurement Readiness Checklist
	18.	Conclusion + Next Steps
	19.	Appendix

	•	Source list
	•	KPI definitions
	•	Assumptions log
	•	Sample workflows and templates

Length expectation: equivalent of 15–25 pages of text (single-spaced), plus appendices.

5) Must-have SIG use cases (and expand beyond)

At minimum include these categories and frame each around growth/efficiency:
	•	Trading/market-facing: event digestion, precedent retrieval, rules/terms diffs
	•	Quant research: research lineage synthesis, experiment consolidation, documentation packs
	•	Risk: policy+precedent synthesis, post-mortem reuse, monitoring narratives
	•	Legal/compliance: covenant extraction, amendment diffs, audit response packs
	•	Memo production: evidence-backed drafts, standardized templates, repeatable deliverables

Also add at least 5 additional SIG-relevant workflows that represent high ROI.

6) Writing style constraints
	•	Enterprise sales voice: crisp, confident, precise, non-hype.
	•	Keep every section anchored in strategic growth and operational efficiency outcomes.
	•	Quant sections must show math clearly (tables, assumptions, ranges).
	•	Every major claim must be supported with citations or flagged as an assumption.

7) Output formatting
	•	Provide the full proposal in one continuous document.
	•	After the proposal, provide:
	1.	A 1-page executive brief focused on growth + operating leverage
	2.	A slide-by-slide pitch deck outline (15–20 slides) that maps to the proposal sections, with concise bullets and recommended visuals per slide in Hebbia style (grid layouts, stat tiles, thin-line icons, blue chips, glass callouts).

8) Quality bar

This must read like a top-tier enterprise AE deliverable: deeply researched, quantified, objection-ready, and explicitly tied to growth capacity creation and operating efficiency for SIG.

output.cover_and_disclaimer:
PROPOSAL FOR ENTERPRISE AI PARTNERSHIP

Prepared for:
Susquehanna International Group (SIG)
401 City Avenue
Bala Cynwyd, PA 19004

Prepared by:
Hebbia AI

Date: December 18, 2025

Subject: A Strategic Proposal to Unlock Growth Capacity and Operating Leverage at Susquehanna International Group through Enterprise-Grade AI Reasoning.

Disclaimer:
This document is a confidential proposal prepared by Hebbia for discussion purposes with Susquehanna International Group (SIG) and its designated representatives. The information contained herein is based on publicly available data, industry benchmarks, and Hebbia's analysis as of the date of this proposal. While every effort has been made to ensure accuracy, Hebbia makes no warranties or representations regarding the completeness or accuracy of the information. All quantitative models, including ROI projections and efficiency gains, are estimates based on stated assumptions and should be considered illustrative. This proposal does not constitute a binding offer. The contents of this document are proprietary and confidential to Hebbia. It is not to be reproduced, distributed, or disclosed to any third party without the prior written consent of Hebbia. This proposal does not imply that SIG is a current customer of Hebbia or that it has endorsed any products or services described herein.

executive_summary.growth_opportunity_summary: Hebbia's enterprise AI platform is engineered to directly address constraints on strategic growth by creating significant new capacity within Susquehanna International Group's (SIG) existing expert teams. By automating and accelerating the labor-intensive processes of multi-document research, synthesis, and analysis, Hebbia enables SIG's traders, quantitative researchers, and analysts to evaluate a greater volume and complexity of opportunities per unit of time. This translates into the ability to expand coverage across new markets, instruments, and counterparties, and to respond to market-moving events with faster, data-backed conviction. The platform allows for the scaling of high-quality, evidence-based outputs—such as research memos, risk assessments, and compliance reviews—without a corresponding linear increase in headcount, turning SIG's vast internal and external data repositories into a source of compounding strategic advantage.
executive_summary.operating_leverage_gains: The primary driver of operating leverage through Hebbia is the radical compression of decision cycle times and the reduction of high-cost manual effort in knowledge-intensive workflows. Hebbia's platform is proven to reduce document review and analysis time by up to 75% for complex tasks like credit agreement analysis and save 20-40 hours per deal in diligence processes. For SIG, this means significantly reducing the time-to-conviction for trading decisions, minimizing duplicated diligence by creating a searchable and reusable institutional memory, and decreasing the coordination overhead required to assemble context for complex analyses. By providing a verifiable, auditable, and consistent reasoning layer across all document-based research, Hebbia reduces variance in outputs and frees thousands of expert hours from routine data extraction to focus on higher-value strategic thinking and alpha generation.
executive_summary.quantified_roi_highlight: Based on conservative models derived from industry benchmarks and Hebbia's documented performance at peer financial institutions, we project a multi-year Return on Investment (ROI) for SIG in the range of 250-400%. The principal value driver is the redeployment of saved expert hours towards growth-oriented activities. For example, a 25% efficiency gain for a team of 50 quantitative researchers and analysts could unlock over 25,000 hours of high-value strategic capacity annually. This translates into millions of dollars in value, derived from increased decision throughput and expanded analytical coverage. The ROI model, detailed later in this proposal, accounts for license costs, implementation, and change management, demonstrating a projected payback period of less than 18 months and a significant positive Net Present Value (NPV).
executive_summary.strategic_recommendation: Our primary recommendation is for Susquehanna International Group to engage in a 6-8 week, fully-supported pilot program with a targeted team of 5-10 professionals (e.g., from quant research, trading support, or compliance). The objective of this pilot is to empirically validate the efficiency gains and growth capacity creation projected in this proposal against a set of mutually defined, high-value use cases and success metrics. This focused engagement will provide SIG with a data-driven basis to assess the platform's full-scale enterprise value and will allow Hebbia to demonstrate its capabilities within SIG's unique operational and security environment, at no risk to ongoing operations.

sig_strategic_context.business_lines_overview: Susquehanna International Group (SIG) operates a diversified portfolio of businesses centered on quantitative trading and technology. Its primary business is a global market maker and algorithmic trading company, engaging in proprietary investments across a vast array of asset classes including equities, fixed income, energy, commodities, indices, and derivative products. SIG is a major participant in options trading, acting as a specialist for approximately 600 equity options and 45 index options on major exchanges. The firm's U.S. trading unit, Susquehanna Securities, traded 2.7 billion options contracts in 2023. Beyond its core trading, SIG operates Susquehanna Financial Group (SFG), its institutional broker-dealer arm, which provides order execution, trading flow services, and equity research. The firm has also made significant inroads into private equity and venture capital through several affiliates, including Heights Capital Management (focusing on PIPE transactions), SIG China (a major VC in China with over 350 investments), Susquehanna Growth Equity (investing in software and information services), and Susquehanna Structured Capital. This diversification extends to sports analytics through Nellie Analytics and sustainable investments, showcasing a broad application of its quantitative expertise.
sig_strategic_context.operating_model_and_culture: SIG's operating model is deeply rooted in a culture of scientific rigor, intellectual curiosity, innovation, and a strong emphasis on decision science and game theory, principles derived from its founders' background in poker. The culture is highly collaborative, breaking down silos between researchers, engineers, and traders to foster a continuous, iterative process of strategy development and system refinement. This 'tech-empowered trading' approach is central to its operations, with over 1,000 technologists supporting a global infrastructure of more than 20,000 servers. The firm's training and daily operations are infused with strategic games to teach decision-making under uncertainty. This systematic, data-driven, and analytical approach underpins all its activities, from developing complex trading algorithms to managing risk, creating a high-performance environment that prioritizes problem-solving and continuous learning over rigid corporate structures.
sig_strategic_context.scale_and_global_presence: SIG is a significant global entity with a substantial physical and market presence. As of 2024-2025, the firm employs over 3,200 people worldwide. Its headquarters are in Bala Cynwyd, Pennsylvania, and it operates from 14 to 17+ offices globally, including major financial centers like New York, Chicago, San Francisco, Dublin, London, Sydney, Shanghai, and Tokyo. The firm's financial scale is considerable, with a reported revenue of $7.2 billion in 2024. In terms of market activity, as of 2018, SIG was responsible for trading approximately 7% of U.S. ETF volume and over $1.5 trillion in ETFs globally each year. Its options trading volume is also substantial, with its U.S. unit trading 2.7 billion contracts in 2023. While a comprehensive firm-wide AUM is not publicly disclosed, various filings for its affiliates indicate portfolio values in the billions, reflecting a large and active investment footprint.
sig_strategic_context.inferred_growth_constraints: While SIG's operating model is highly optimized for efficiency, its growth is inherently constrained by the speed and scale at which human experts can convert vast amounts of unstructured data into actionable, decision-ready insights. The primary constraint is not inefficiency but the natural ceiling on human analytical capacity. This 'decision latency'—the time taken to perform due diligence, digest market-moving events from news and filings, review complex legal documents, and synthesize findings from disparate research—limits the number of opportunities that can be evaluated and the speed at which the firm can react. Even with advanced technology, the manual and cognitive effort required for deep, document-based reasoning creates a bottleneck. Scaling these high-quality analytical outputs (memos, briefs, reviews) requires a near-linear increase in expert headcount, representing a significant constraint on achieving non-linear operating leverage and growth capacity.

problem_statement.core_challenge: The core challenge for Susquehanna International Group is the inherent latency and scalability limit in converting the massive, continuous influx of unstructured data—spanning news feeds, regulatory filings, earnings transcripts, legal agreements, and internal research—into the decision-ready, verifiable insights required to maintain a competitive edge. In an environment where alpha decays rapidly, the speed of high-quality, deep-dive analysis is a fundamental bottleneck. The process remains dependent on manual, cognitive-intensive workflows, which are linear and cannot scale at the same pace as the data universe, creating a structural constraint on the firm's ability to generate and act on novel insights.
problem_statement.impact_on_decision_velocity: This decision latency acts as a direct constraint on SIG's decision velocity and, consequently, its ability to capitalize on market opportunities. Every hour that quantitative researchers, traders, and legal experts spend on manual document review, context assembly, and duplicated diligence is an hour not spent on higher-order strategic thinking, model refinement, and alpha generation. This delay can mean the difference between capturing a fleeting opportunity and missing it, limiting the expansion of analytical coverage to new markets or instruments, and slowing the firm's overall responsiveness to a dynamic global landscape. It effectively places a ceiling on the throughput of high-conviction ideas the firm can generate and execute upon.
problem_statement.quantified_opportunity_cost: The opportunity cost associated with these manual, document-intensive workflows is substantial. Based on industry benchmarks and Hebbia's documented impact, we can estimate this cost. For example, a 75% reduction in the time to review a credit agreement, which can take 4-8 hours manually, frees up 3-6 hours of expert legal or analyst time per document. For investment banking-style diligence, saving 20-30 hours per deal translates directly into capacity to evaluate more opportunities. Assuming a conservative fully loaded labor rate of $250/hour for an analyst, saving 10 hours per week per analyst on document-based research translates to an opportunity cost of $130,000 per analyst annually. Across a team of 25 analysts, this represents over $3.25 million in lost capacity or efficiency per year, time that could be reallocated to expanding coverage or deepening research quality.

value_thesis.primary_thesis: Hebbia provides critical operating leverage to Susquehanna International Group by transforming document-based research and diligence from a manual, linear-scaling workflow into a scalable, AI-powered reasoning engine. By automating the low-level tasks of data extraction and synthesis, Hebbia empowers SIG's world-class talent to focus on high-level strategic analysis, thereby increasing decision throughput and expanding growth capacity without a proportional increase in headcount.
value_thesis.growth_enablement_mechanism: Hebbia directly enables strategic growth by creating new analytical capacity. By drastically reducing the time-to-conviction for evaluating opportunities, the platform allows SIG's teams to increase their decision throughput—evaluating more scenarios, markets, instruments, and counterparties per unit of time. This expansion of analytical coverage means more potential alpha-generating ideas can be explored and validated. Hebbia allows the firm to scale the production of high-quality outputs like research memos and diligence reports, effectively decoupling analytical output from linear headcount growth and enabling a more agile response to market events.
value_thesis.efficiency_and_leverage_driver: Hebbia is a powerful driver of operational efficiency and leverage by fundamentally compressing research and diligence cycle times. It automates the most labor-intensive aspects of knowledge work, such as precedent retrieval, covenant extraction from legal agreements, and synthesizing data from multiple documents. This automation eliminates thousands of hours of manual labor, reduces duplicated diligence by creating a searchable institutional memory, and minimizes the coordination overhead required to assemble context for a decision. Documented use cases show time reductions of over 75% for specific tasks, translating directly into significant cost savings and freeing up expert resources.
value_thesis.defensibility_and_quality_improvement: Hebbia enhances decision quality and defensibility, which in turn unlocks the confidence to move faster. Its core 'citation-first' architecture provides a fully traceable, auditable, and verifiable reasoning trail for every piece of information it generates. Every number, clause, or summary is hyperlinked back to its precise origin in the source documents. This 'verifiable fact layer' mitigates AI hallucination risk, ensures consistency, and creates a robust governance framework suitable for regulatory scrutiny. By building a compounding, evidence-backed institutional memory, Hebbia improves the quality and defensibility of every decision, fostering a culture of high-conviction, high-velocity execution.

hebbia_overview.company_profile: Hebbia is an American artificial intelligence technology company founded in August 2020 by George Sivulka. The company specializes in developing AI platforms for knowledge-intensive industries, with a primary focus on finance, law, and consulting. Hebbia has established a strong position in the enterprise AI market, having secured over $160 million in funding, including a significant $130 million Series B round in July 2024, which brought its valuation to an estimated $700 million. The company is backed by prominent investors such as Andreessen Horowitz (a16z), Index Ventures, Google Ventures, and Peter Thiel. Hebbia's client roster includes leading global entities such as BlackRock, KKR, and the U.S. Air Force, demonstrating its adoption in high-stakes, security-conscious environments. The platform is utilized by firms managing a collective total of over $25 trillion in Assets Under Management (AUM) and has over 1,000 live use cases in production, showcasing its maturity and widespread application after five years of deployment in top-tier firms.
hebbia_overview.key_differentiators: Hebbia's unique value proposition is centered on its proprietary technology that addresses the core limitations of traditional AI systems in complex enterprise workflows. A key differentiator is its ISD (Information, Synthesis, Decomposition) architecture, which functions as an 'agentic orchestrator.' Unlike standard Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems, which Hebbia found to fail in 84% of complex real-world queries, the ISD architecture decomposes complex questions into multiple logical sub-tasks. It then deploys a team of specialized AI agents in parallel, routing each task to the most suitable model (e.g., vision models for charts, legally-tuned models for contracts), achieving 92% accuracy on rigorous financial and legal benchmarks. This architecture enables what Hebbia describes as an 'infinite effective context window,' allowing the platform to reason across thousands of documents simultaneously, processing full documents rather than just snippets. Another core tenet is its 'citation-first' approach, which ensures total transparency and auditability. Every piece of data generated by the AI—whether a number, clause, or summary—is hyperlinked directly back to its precise origin in the source documents, creating a verifiable, machine-readable 'citation trail' that mitigates hallucination risk and provides a defensible 'verifiable fact layer'.
hebbia_overview.proven_financial_sector_impact: Hebbia provides verifiable claims and case studies demonstrating substantial impact within the financial and legal sectors. The platform is used by firms managing over $25 trillion in Assets Under Management (AUM) and has processed over 2 trillion tokens for investors across more than 1,000 live use cases. An official OpenAI case study highlights Hebbia's ability to automate up to 90% of finance and legal work, yielding significant efficiency gains. Specific, quantified outcomes include: investment bankers saving 30–40 hours per deal on tasks like research synthesis and due diligence; private equity firms saving 20–30 hours per deal on screening and expert network research; and law firms reducing credit agreement review time by 75%, which translates to an estimated savings of $2,000 per hour in legal fees. Other reported metrics include a 5x faster review of Offering Memorandums, a 137% increase in identified opportunities, a 3x increase in leveraged data, and 95% faster contract analysis. These claims are supported by its adoption at top-tier firms, where C-suite executives have reportedly called it 'the first actually useful AI,' underscoring its tangible value in high-stakes professional environments.

product_deep_dive.matrix_platform_description: The Hebbia Matrix is the company's flagship product, functioning as a sophisticated enterprise reasoning interface designed for complex, document-heavy workflows. Described as an 'interface to AGI,' its UI is intentionally designed to resemble a familiar tool like Microsoft Excel, organizing documents as rows and user questions as columns. The cells are then populated with AI-generated answers, each with a direct citation to the source material. This grid-based, collaborative interface is engineered to reduce cognitive friction and allow users to observe, interact with, and guide the AI's reasoning process. At its core, Matrix is a multi-agent AI platform powered by Hebbia's proprietary ISD (Information, Synthesis, Decomposition) architecture. This system orchestrates a variety of specialized AI models in parallel, including OpenAI's o3-mini, o1, and GPT-4o, to break down complex queries into logical sub-tasks. It is natively multimodal, capable of reasoning over diverse data types such as charts, tables, PDFs, images, email chains, and presentations, effectively providing an 'infinite context window' to synthesize information across thousands of files simultaneously.
product_deep_dive.hebbia_agents_capabilities: Hebbia Agents are specialized AI models that form the operational core of the Matrix platform's multi-agent architecture. Instead of relying on a single monolithic model, Hebbia deploys a team of these agents in parallel, each optimized for a specific task within a complex workflow. When a user poses a complex query, the ISD orchestration engine decomposes it into multiple logical steps and routes each sub-task to the most appropriate agent—for example, a vision model for analyzing a chart, a legally-tuned model for interpreting a contract, or a quantitative model for extracting financial data. These agents can perform a wide range of functions, including news parsing, sentiment analysis, entity extraction, legal clause identification, and strategy pattern recognition. A specific example is the 'Deeper Research' agent, which is designed to expand data sourcing beyond uploaded documents to include private files, specialized financial databases like PitchBook and S&P CapIQ, and general web sources, all while maintaining a complete, auditable trail back to the original source. This agentic approach allows Hebbia to handle complex, multi-step reasoning with higher accuracy and reliability than traditional RAG systems.
product_deep_dive.hebbia_draft_functionality: Hebbia Draft is a core product component designed to generate structured, evidence-backed outputs from the analysis performed by the Matrix platform and its agents. While Matrix and the agents handle the complex reasoning and data extraction across vast document sets, Draft serves as the final synthesis and presentation layer. It takes the synthesized findings, complete with their verifiable citations, and formats them into polished, client-ready deliverables. This functionality is crucial for transforming raw analysis into actionable intelligence. For example, after agents have compared two versions of a legal agreement, Draft can generate a clean redline report or a concise summary of key changes. Similarly, it can be used to produce comprehensive research memos, populate standardized templates with extracted data, create reproducible research reports, or draft investment committee briefs. Every piece of information within a document generated by Draft maintains the 'citation-first' principle, linking back to the original source material to ensure full transparency and defensibility.

security_governance_and_auditability.compliance_and_certifications: Hebbia maintains a robust compliance posture designed for high-stakes, regulated industries like finance and law. The company is SOC 2 Type I and Type II compliant, which attests to its stringent internal controls over security, availability, processing integrity, confidentiality, and privacy. Furthermore, Hebbia is fully GDPR compliant, adhering to European data protection regulations, and is also compliant with the California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA). This comprehensive set of certifications demonstrates Hebbia's commitment to meeting rigorous third-party security and privacy standards, making it suitable for enterprises handling sensitive data. The platform's approval for use by the United States Air Force serves as additional evidence of its validated, high-security credentials.
security_governance_and_auditability.data_privacy_and_handling_policy: Hebbia's data privacy and handling policy is centered on a strict and explicit commitment to never train its AI models on user data. This foundational policy ensures complete data isolation and confidentiality, preventing any cross-contamination of information between clients and protecting sensitive intellectual property or Material Non-Public Information (MNPI). All customer data is treated as confidential and is encrypted both at rest using the AES-256 standard and in transit using TLS 1.3. Hebbia also maintains a dedicated Data Protection Officer to oversee its privacy program and handle related inquiries, reinforcing its commitment to responsible data stewardship.
security_governance_and_auditability.governance_and_access_controls: The Hebbia platform incorporates comprehensive governance and access control features to ensure secure enterprise deployment. It supports seamless integration with enterprise Single Sign-On (SSO) providers such as Okta and Azure AD, utilizing standard protocols like SAML and OAuth2 to enforce unified authentication policies. The platform implements granular access controls through both Role-Based Access Control (RBAC), which defines permissions based on user roles (e.g., 'Analyst', 'Admin'), and Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC), which allows for more dynamic permissions based on user, resource, and environmental attributes. This ensures adherence to the principle of least privilege. Furthermore, Hebbia supports the System for Cross-domain Identity Management (SCIM) protocol to automate user and group provisioning and de-provisioning, ensuring that access rights are consistently and efficiently managed in alignment with the enterprise's central identity provider.
security_governance_and_auditability.auditability_and_traceability_features: Full auditability and traceability are core pillars of the Hebbia platform, designed to provide total transparency and meet the stringent requirements of regulated industries. This is primarily achieved through its 'citation-first' principle, which creates a verifiable fact layer for all AI-generated outputs. Every piece of information, whether a number, a summary, or an extracted clause, is hyperlinked directly back to its precise location within the original source document. This creates an immutable, machine-readable 'citation trail' that allows users and auditors to 'see the work' and trace every action the AI takes. In addition to this content-level traceability, the platform maintains comprehensive logs of all user activities, data access events, and system changes. These logs can be integrated with an enterprise's Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) system for continuous monitoring, providing a complete and defensible audit trail for compliance and regulatory scrutiny.

sig_use_case_portfolio.business_objective: Operational Efficiency (reduce time to assess market events, improve decision speed) & Growth Capacity (enable faster response to new trading opportunities).
sig_use_case_portfolio.stakeholders: Trading Desk Leads, Portfolio Managers, Quant Analysts.
sig_use_case_portfolio.inputs_and_systems: Real-time news feeds, regulatory announcements, earnings call transcripts, analyst reports, social media sentiment, internal trading logs, market data (price, volume).
sig_use_case_portfolio.workflow_steps: Hebbia Agents continuously ingest and monitor diverse real-time and historical data sources. Matrix orchestrates agents to identify significant trading events (e.g., M&A rumors, regulatory changes, geopolitical shifts), extract key entities, quantify sentiment, and correlate with historical market reactions. ISD ensures precise linking to original news articles or reports. Deep Research chat allows traders to query specific event impacts or historical precedents.
sig_use_case_portfolio.outputs_and_definition_of_done: Real-time event summaries with sentiment scores, identified impacted assets, historical correlation reports, alerts for significant deviations, and evidence-backed impact assessments.
sig_use_case_portfolio.hebbia_product_mapping:
Matrix: Orchestrates multiple agents for continuous monitoring, data ingestion, and analysis across diverse sources.
Agents: Specialized agents for news parsing, sentiment analysis, entity extraction, and correlation.
ISD: Ensures full traceability to original news sources and reports, critical for high-stakes trading decisions.
Deep Research: Enables ad-hoc querying of event impacts and historical data.
sig_use_case_portfolio.measurable_kpis:
Event digestion cycle time: 50% reduction (e.g., from 30 mins to 15 mins).
Throughput: 2x increase in events analyzed per hour.
Decision speed: 15% faster reaction to market-moving news.
Error/Variance: <2% misclassification of event impact.
sig_use_case_portfolio.adoption_notes_and_risks: Requires robust integration with SIG's real-time data infrastructure. Initial skepticism from traders accustomed to manual news digestion. Focus on demonstrating accuracy and speed benefits in a pilot phase. Data security and latency are critical considerations.

sig_use_case_portfolio.use_case_title: Precedent Retrieval for Trading Strategies & Legal Opinions
sig_use_case_portfolio.business_objective: Operational Efficiency (reduce research time, improve consistency) & Growth Capacity (accelerate development of new strategies, strengthen legal positions).
sig_use_case_portfolio.stakeholders: Quant Researchers, Legal & Compliance Teams, Trading Strategists.
sig_use_case_portfolio.inputs_and_systems: Historical trading strategy documents, internal legal opinions, regulatory guidance, past litigation records, academic papers, market microstructure research, internal memos, external legal databases.
sig_use_case_portfolio.workflow_steps: Hebbia Agents ingest and index a vast library of internal and external documents. Users leverage Deep Research chat to query for precedents related to specific trading conditions, regulatory interpretations, or legal challenges. Matrix orchestrates agents to identify relevant clauses, historical outcomes, and expert opinions, presenting them with precise source-linking via ISD. Draft can then be used to synthesize findings into a structured report.
sig_use_case_portfolio.outputs_and_definition_of_done: Comprehensive precedent reports, identified similar cases/strategies, relevant clauses/interpretations, and synthesized summaries with source citations.
sig_use_case_portfolio.hebbia_product_mapping:
Deep Research: Enables querying across diverse, vast internal and external knowledge bases.
Agents: Specialized agents for legal document analysis, clause extraction, and strategy pattern recognition.
ISD: Guarantees precise source-linking for defensible legal opinions and robust strategy development.
Matrix: Orchestrates the retrieval and synthesis process.
Draft: For generating structured precedent reports.
sig_use_case_portfolio.measurable_kpis:
Research cycle time: 40% reduction (e.g., from 2 hours to 1.2 hours).
Throughput: 30% increase in precedents reviewed per day.

quantified_value_hypothesis.capacity_creation_model: This model quantifies how Hebbia creates new analytical capacity by reducing the 'Time-to-Conviction' (TTC) and thereby increasing 'Decision Throughput'. TTC is modeled as the sum of information gathering, processing, cognitive review, and verification times. Hebbia is expected to significantly reduce each component through its deep research, multi-agent AI workflows, and citation-backed outputs. The increase in capacity is then modeled using the principle that throughput is inversely proportional to cycle time (Throughput = 1 / Cycle Time). By reducing the cycle time for an analysis (CT_hebbia), the number of analyses that can be completed per period increases. The model calculates the 'Throughput Increase Factor' as (CT_baseline / CT_hebbia) and 'Additional Analyses per Week' as (Baseline Analyses per Week) * (Throughput Increase Factor - 1). For example, AI-augmented equity research can free up 24 hours per week per analyst, allowing for 15.5 hours of strategic analysis, implying a significant increase in higher-value output and expanded coverage without increasing headcount.
quantified_value_hypothesis.operational_efficiency_model: This model quantifies cost reductions from three primary sources: reduced labor hours, lower rework rates, and compressed cycle times. The core formula for cost savings is 'Total Labor Hours Saved * Fully Loaded Labor Rate'. Total Labor Hours Saved is calculated as '(Baseline Hours per Task - Hebbia Hours per Task) * Number of Tasks'. The model also accounts for 'Rework Cost Savings' calculated as '(Baseline Rework Rate - Hebbia Rework Rate) * Total Task Cost'. To apply this to SIG, the model requires staffing assumptions for roles like Quant Researchers, Traders, and Compliance Reviewers, along with their fully loaded labor rates (estimated to range from $100 to $600+ per hour depending on the role). Illustrative scenarios show that with just 10 Quant Researchers saving 10 hours per week each, weekly savings could be $35,000, demonstrating significant potential for cost reduction across various departments.
quantified_value_hypothesis.risk_cost_proxy_model: This model estimates the value of avoided costs by mitigating operational risks, such as oversight misses or failures to identify relevant precedents. The methodology involves three steps: 1) Identify key risk areas (e.g., compliance, operational risk, legal). 2) Estimate the baseline annual probability of a risk event and its average financial impact (fines, losses, reputational damage). 3) Quantify the percentage reduction in that probability or impact attributable to Hebbia's improved analysis and oversight capabilities. A representative formula is: 'Avoided Compliance Fines = (Baseline Annual Fine Probability * Average Fine Amount) * % Reduction in Probability due to Hebbia'. Another example is modeling savings from reduced false positives in AML investigations. The model is heavily caveated, acknowledging the difficulty in quantifying the probability of rare, high-impact events and isolating AI's specific contribution to risk reduction.

pilot_plan.pilot_objectives_and_scope: The primary objective of the 6-8 week pilot program is to validate Hebbia's value proposition within Susquehanna International Group's (SIG) specific environment and workflows. The pilot aims to provide tangible, data-backed evidence of Hebbia's ability to drive strategic growth capacity and operational efficiency. The scope is intentionally focused to ensure measurable outcomes within the limited timeframe. It involves identifying 1-2 specific, high-impact use cases within a single, well-defined department. Recommended departments include quant research, trading desk support, or compliance review, as these areas involve document-intensive tasks where Hebbia's core strengths—such as multi-document synthesis, verifiable citations, and complex reasoning—can be clearly demonstrated. The pilot will involve a select group of 5-10 users (e.g., quant researchers, analysts, compliance officers) who will use Hebbia to perform their regular tasks, allowing for a direct comparison against existing manual processes. The pilot will focus on processing a combination of SIG's private data (e.g., internal research notes, historical trade analysis, compliance documents) and pre-indexed public data (e.g., company filings) to test the platform's full capabilities.
pilot_plan.timeline_and_phases:
The 6-8 week pilot is structured into three distinct phases to ensure a methodical progression from setup to evaluation.

**Phase 1: Setup & Baseline (Weeks 1-2)**
*   **Activities:** The Hebbia environment will be provisioned and secured according to SIG's IT and security requirements. The pilot team will identify and complete the initial data ingestion from selected internal document repositories (e.g., SharePoint, network drives). Crucially, the SIG project manager and pilot users will establish and document baseline metrics for the current manual processes. This includes measuring the time spent on specific research tasks, the accuracy of data extraction, and the typical cycle time for producing analytical outputs.
*   **Milestones:** Secure Hebbia environment is live; initial dataset is ingested and indexed; baseline performance metrics are formally documented and signed off.

**Phase 2: Usage & Iteration (Weeks 3-6)**
*   **Activities:** The 5-10 pilot users will receive comprehensive training and begin actively using the Hebbia platform for their defined use cases. They will be encouraged to use both the intuitive chat and the advanced Matrix interfaces. Regular feedback sessions (e.g., twice weekly) will be held to gather user input, address any technical issues, and refine Hebbia's AI prompts and data handling to better suit SIG's specific needs. The Hebbia support team will provide dedicated, white-glove support throughout this phase.
*   **Milestones:** All pilot users are trained; a minimum of 80% user engagement is achieved; at least four feedback sessions are conducted; initial integration points with SIG's workflow are tested.

**Phase 3: Evaluation & Reporting (Weeks 7-8)**
*   **Activities:** All usage data and user feedback from the pilot are collected and analyzed. The SIG project manager, in collaboration with the Hebbia team, will conduct a comprehensive evaluation of the pilot's results against the predefined success metrics. A final report will be generated, including a quantitative analysis of efficiency gains, qualitative user feedback, and a clear recommendation for a broader, phased rollout.
*   **Milestones:** Pilot data analysis is complete; a final, detailed report is presented to all stakeholders; a go/no-go decision for a full rollout is made.
pilot_plan.roles_and_responsibilities:
Clear roles and responsibilities are defined to ensure accountability and effective collaboration during the pilot.

**Susquehanna International Group (SIG) Roles:**
*   **Executive Sponsor:** A senior leader (e.g., CTO, Head of Quant Research) who champions the pilot, secures resources, and acts as the primary decision-maker.
*   **Dedicated Project Manager:** The primary point of contact for SIG, responsible for overseeing the pilot from start to finish, coordinating internal resources, tracking progress against milestones, and compiling the final evaluation report.
*   **Pilot Users (5-10):** A group of quant researchers, analysts, or compliance officers who will actively use Hebbia, provide regular feedback, and participate in performance measurement.
*   **IT/Security Liaison:** A representative from SIG's technology and security teams responsible for overseeing the secure provisioning of the Hebbia environment, data integration, and ensuring compliance with all internal security policies.

**Hebbia Roles:**
*   **Account Executive:** The primary commercial contact, responsible for the overall relationship and ensuring the pilot aligns with strategic goals.
*   **Technical Lead/AI Strategist:** The main technical point of contact from Hebbia, responsible for leading the environment setup, guiding data ingestion, providing expert guidance on use case implementation, and offering 'white-glove' onboarding and support.
*   **Support Team:** A dedicated team available to address any technical issues, answer user questions, and ensure a smooth user experience throughout the pilot.
pilot_plan.success_metrics_and_criteria:
The success of the pilot will be evaluated against a combination of quantitative and qualitative metrics, tied directly to the core value proposition of driving growth and efficiency. These criteria will be used to make a data-driven decision on a full enterprise rollout.

**Quantitative Metrics:**
*   **Efficiency Gains:** A minimum of a 25% reduction in the time and resources required to complete the targeted pilot tasks (e.g., time-to-conviction for an investment thesis, cycle time for a compliance review) compared to the established baseline. This will be a primary indicator of operational efficiency.
*   **Return on Investment (ROI) Projection:** The pilot data will be used to project a full-scale ROI, with a target of exceeding 250% over a three-year period. This metric is owned by the CFO persona.
*   **Time-to-Value (TTV) Projection:** The pilot should demonstrate that significant value can be achieved quickly, with a projected TTV of under 9 months for a full rollout. This metric is owned by the CTO persona.
*   **Throughput Increase:** A measurable increase in the number of analyses, reports, or reviews that can be completed by the pilot users in a given week.

**Qualitative Metrics:**
*   **User Satisfaction and Adoption:** A high adoption rate (e.g., >80% of pilot users actively using the platform weekly) and overwhelmingly positive qualitative feedback from users regarding usability, performance, and impact on their daily work. This will be measured via surveys and feedback sessions.
*   **Accuracy and Reliability:** A critical evaluation of Hebbia's output quality. Success is defined by the generation of verifiable, accurate answers with high precision and minimal to zero instances of AI 'hallucination'. The traceability of every answer back to the source document is a key criterion.
*   **Scalability Assessment:** A positive assessment from the SIG IT/Security liaison on Hebbia's technical architecture, security posture, and its ability to scale to meet enterprise-wide demand.

rollout_and_change_management_plan.ninety_day_plan:
The first 90 days are structured as a 'Partner Enablement Plan' focused on building a strong foundation for enterprise-wide adoption.

*   **Days 1-30: Foundational Onboarding & Training:** The primary goal is to equip the initial core teams at SIG with deep product knowledge. This involves comprehensive product training sessions led by Hebbia's AI strategists, covering both basic and advanced features of the Matrix and chat interfaces. Access will be provisioned to Hebbia's dedicated enablement portal, which contains resources, tutorials, and best practice guides. The key goal is to have 100% of the initial partner team certified on the Hebbia platform.

*   **Days 31-60: Co-development of Playbooks & Use Case Expansion:** This phase focuses on collaboration. SIG and Hebbia teams will jointly develop Go-To-Market (GTM) playbooks for internal adoption, tailoring messaging and use cases for different SIG departments (e.g., quant research, private equity, legal). Hebbia will run a series of demo workshops to showcase the platform's capabilities to a broader internal audience, aiming to identify and initiate at least 5 new qualified internal pilots or use cases beyond the initial trial.

*   **Days 61-90: Internal Launch & Performance Tracking:** The focus shifts to driving awareness and tracking initial impact. Internal co-marketing campaigns will be launched to promote Hebbia's benefits across SIG. The initial set of internal deals/use cases will be closely tracked to measure early wins and calculate potential cost savings and efficiency gains. The target is to build a pipeline of potential value equivalent to $500K and achieve an 80% user satisfaction score from these early adopters.
rollout_and_change_management_plan.one_eighty_day_plan:
Building on the foundation of the first 90 days, the period from day 91 to 180 is focused on structured expansion and demonstrating broader value across the organization.

*   **Activities:** The primary activity is the execution of the 5+ new pilots identified in the first 90 days. This involves onboarding new teams and departments, providing them with tailored training, and integrating Hebbia into their specific workflows. The focus will be on expanding to adjacent teams of the initial pilot group and into new business lines, such as SIG's private equity and venture capital affiliates. The Hebbia and SIG project teams will work to codify the successful workflows from the initial pilots into standardized templates and 'playbooks' that can be easily replicated. Success stories and quantitative results from the first 90 days will be actively socialized to build momentum and encourage adoption.

*   **Goals:** The goal is to successfully complete at least three new departmental pilots, demonstrating Hebbia's value across a diverse set of use cases. Another key goal is to gather more extensive data on efficiency gains and time savings to refine the enterprise-wide ROI model. By day 180, a comprehensive business case, supported by multi-departmental evidence, should be ready for presentation to senior leadership to secure commitment for a full enterprise-wide rollout.
rollout_and_change_management_plan.three_sixty_five_day_plan:
The first year culminates in achieving enterprise-wide scale and fully realizing the strategic value of the Hebbia partnership.

*   **Activities:** Based on the success of the phased pilots, the plan is to execute a full, enterprise-wide rollout of Hebbia to all identified user groups across SIG's global operations. This includes all relevant trading desks, quant research teams, risk and compliance departments, legal teams, and operational units. The focus will be on deeply embedding Hebbia into standard business processes, making it a core component of SIG's knowledge work infrastructure. A permanent Center of Excellence (CoE) for AI will be established within SIG to govern the platform, manage user licenses, develop new use cases, and provide ongoing internal support and training. Hebbia will transition from a high-touch onboarding model to a strategic partnership role, focusing on co-innovation and identifying new opportunities for value creation.

*   **Goals:** The primary goal is to achieve the projected ROI and operational efficiency targets outlined in the initial proposal. Success is defined by high adoption rates (>80%) across all targeted departments, a measurable impact on SIG's ability to evaluate opportunities and scale high-quality analysis, and the establishment of a self-sustaining governance model for AI tools. By the end of the first year, Hebbia should be an indispensable tool for knowledge work at SIG, contributing to its competitive advantage.
rollout_and_change_management_plan.governance_and_kpi_cadence:
A structured governance model and regular KPI review cadence will be established to ensure the rollout stays on track and delivers measurable value.

*   **Governance Forums:** A steering committee comprising executive sponsors from SIG and Hebbia leadership will meet quarterly to review strategic progress, ROI, and long-term planning. A monthly operational review meeting will be held with project managers and team leads to discuss KPI trends, user feedback, and tactical adjustments. Weekly dashboards will provide real-time visibility into key adoption metrics.

*   **KPI Cadence:**
    *   **Weekly:** Dashboards will track user engagement metrics such as Daily Active Users (DAU), Monthly Active Users (MAU), and adoption rates by department. This provides an early warning system for adoption challenges.
    *   **Monthly:** Detailed reports will be generated to analyze trends in key performance indicators (e.g., time saved per analysis, number of documents processed). This report will also include analysis of user feedback and results from any A/B tests on new features or workflows.
    *   **Quarterly:** A comprehensive business review will be conducted, focusing on the overall ROI of the deployment. This includes a review of Time-to-Value for new use cases, the expansion rate of Hebbia into new teams, and user retention metrics. This forum will make strategic decisions about the future direction of the partnership.

integration_and_data_strategy.proposed_architecture:
The proposed target architecture for deploying Hebbia within SIG's environment is a secure, cloud-native model designed to integrate seamlessly while maintaining strict security and compliance. It leverages Hebbia's integration with Microsoft Azure AI Foundry and is composed of several distinct layers:

1.  **Data Ingestion Layer:** This is the entry point for SIG's data. It will use a combination of secure APIs (e.g., Microsoft Graph API for SharePoint/Office365, Confluence REST API), file connectors (SFTP, S3), and database connectors (JDBC/ODBC) to pull data from SIG's various internal and external sources. An essential component is an advanced OCR engine (like Azure Form Recognizer) to process scanned documents and contracts. This layer is responsible for capturing rich metadata and preserving document versioning for auditability.

2.  **Data Processing Layer:** This layer is powered by the Hebbia Platform, running within the secure confines of the Azure AI Foundry. Here, ingested data is processed using Hebbia's proprietary AI, including natural language processing, entity extraction, and insight generation. A critical feature of this layer is Hebbia's strict policy of *never training models on customer data*, ensuring SIG's proprietary information remains isolated. Automated data classification tools will also run here to identify and tag sensitive information like MNPI and PII.

3.  **Data Storage Layer:** Processed data and generated insights are stored in a secure cloud environment, such as Azure Blob Storage or Azure Data Lake. All data is encrypted at rest (AES 256) and in transit (TLS 1.3). For regulatory compliance (e.g., SEC Rule 17a-4), critical records and audit logs will be stored in immutable Write Once, Read Many (WORM) compliant storage.

4.  **Identity and Access Management (IAM) Layer:** This layer governs user access. It will integrate with SIG's enterprise Single Sign-On (SSO) provider (e.g., Okta, Azure AD) via SAML/OIDC. Granular access is enforced through Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) and Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC) to ensure the principle of least privilege. User provisioning will be automated via SCIM.

5.  **Security & Monitoring Layer:** This layer provides comprehensive oversight. All activities are logged and fed into SIG's Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) system for real-time threat detection. The architecture will also align with SIG's Data Loss Prevention (DLP) tools to prevent unauthorized data exfiltration.
integration_and_data_strategy.data_source_integration:
The strategy for connecting to SIG's key data sources is designed to be comprehensive and secure, covering the diverse range of information the firm utilizes.

*   **Internal Data Sources:**
    *   **Document Systems (DMS) & Wikis:** Integration with platforms like SharePoint and Confluence will be achieved via their respective REST APIs (e.g., Microsoft Graph API). This allows Hebbia to index research notes, project documentation, and internal policies directly from the source.
    *   **Email Archives:** Hebbia will connect to SIG's email archiving solution (e.g., Exchange/Office365 archives) using secure protocols like Microsoft Graph or EWS to ingest and analyze business-related communications for e-discovery and compliance purposes.
    *   **Research Notes & Notebooks:** For proprietary research stored in formats like Jupyter notebooks or OneNote, integration will occur via file connectors (SFTP, S3) or direct API access if available, allowing Hebbia to synthesize findings from past experiments.
    *   **Contract Repositories:** Legal documents such as ISDA agreements and CSAs, often stored as PDFs in a DMS or network drive, will be ingested via file connectors. Advanced OCR technology is critical here to accurately extract text and clauses from these image-based or complex documents.

*   **External Data Sources:**
    *   Hebbia comes with pre-built connectors for public data sources like SEC/EDGAR filings. It can also be configured to ingest data from market data providers (e.g., Bloomberg, Refinitiv) and other third-party vendor feeds that SIG subscribes to, typically via API or secure file transfer.
integration_and_data_strategy.data_governance_and_security:
A multi-faceted plan for data governance and security is proposed to meet SIG's stringent requirements as a regulated financial institution.

*   **Data Classification and Handling of MNPI/PII:** A formal data classification taxonomy (e.g., Public, Internal, Confidential, Highly Confidential/MNPI) will be established. Hebbia's ingestion pipeline will use automated tools to scan for and tag sensitive data, supplemented by manual review where necessary. All data classified as MNPI or PII will be subject to the strictest controls, including encryption and highly restrictive access policies. Hebbia's foundational security promise—**never to train its models on customer data**—is the most critical control for protecting SIG's proprietary information and MNPI.

*   **Identity Management and Access Control:** The system will integrate with SIG's enterprise Single Sign-On (SSO) solution (assumed to be Okta or Azure AD) to enforce centralized authentication and mandatory Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA). Access within Hebbia will be governed by a granular Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) and Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC) model. This ensures that users can only access data for which they have a legitimate business need (e.g., a compliance officer can view specific communication records, but a quant researcher cannot), enforcing the principle of least privilege.

*   **Audit Logging and Compliance:** Comprehensive and immutable audit logs will be generated for every user action, data access event, and administrative change within the Hebbia platform. These logs will be streamed in real-time to SIG's SIEM for continuous monitoring and threat detection. The detailed audit trails are designed to be fully compliant with financial regulations like SEC Rule 17a-4 and FINRA Rule 4511, ensuring that all activities are traceable and defensible during regulatory examinations.
integration_and_data_strategy.deployment_model_recommendation:
After analyzing the trade-offs of various deployment options, the strong recommendation for Susquehanna International Group (SIG) is a **VPC (Virtual Private Cloud) / Private Cloud deployment**. This model offers the optimal balance of security, control, compliance, and scalability required by a sophisticated quantitative trading firm.

*   **SaaS (Software as a Service):** While Hebbia's standard SaaS offering is secure (SOC 2 compliant) and convenient, it may not provide the level of control over the network environment and data residency that a firm like SIG requires for its most sensitive research and document intelligence workloads.

*   **On-Premise:** This model offers maximum control but comes with significant drawbacks, including high capital expenditure, substantial operational overhead for maintenance and upgrades, and challenges in scaling infrastructure dynamically. For a non-latency-critical application like document intelligence, the costs and complexities of an on-premise deployment generally outweigh the benefits.

*   **VPC / Private Cloud (Recommended):** Deploying Hebbia within a dedicated VPC inside SIG's own cloud tenancy (e.g., Microsoft Azure) is the recommended approach. This hybrid model provides the best of both worlds: SIG retains full control over the network environment, security configurations (e.g., firewall rules, private endpoints), and data residency, satisfying compliance and security mandates. Simultaneously, it leverages the scalability, resilience, and managed infrastructure benefits of the cloud. This model ensures that Hebbia operates in an isolated environment, completely segregated from SIG's critical low-latency trading systems, while still integrating securely with necessary data sources.

roi_model_and_sensitivity_analysis.model_inputs_and_assumptions: The ROI model is built on a set of key inputs and transparent assumptions. The primary inputs for 'Benefits' include productivity gains (labor hours saved, increased throughput of analyses), risk mitigation (avoided compliance fines, trading losses, investigation costs), and potential revenue enhancement from better decisions. The 'Costs' include Hebbia's license and support fees, one-time implementation costs (integration, data migration), change management and training costs, infrastructure costs (cloud computing), and ongoing operational expenses (MLOps talent, retraining cycles). Critical assumptions that must be logged and varied include the number of users/seats, average hours saved per user, fully loaded labor rates for different roles, baseline cycle times, risk probabilities, the discount rate for NPV calculations (typically 10-25% for fintech), and the user adoption rate trajectory.
roi_model_and_sensitivity_analysis.scenario_analysis_summary: The ROI model incorporates a scenario analysis to project a range of potential outcomes under different conditions. This involves creating three distinct scenarios: a 'low case', a 'base case', and a 'high case'. Each scenario is defined by adjusting key input variables. For example, the 'Adoption Rate' might be set at 50% for the low case, 70% for the base case, and 90% for the high case. Similarly, 'Time Saved per User' could be varied (e.g., 5 hours/week for low, 8 for base, 12 for high). By running the ROI calculation for each of these scenarios over a 1-3 year period, SIG can understand the potential range of financial returns and the conditions required to achieve the high-end projections.
roi_model_and_sensitivity_analysis.key_financial_metrics: The model calculates three key financial metrics to evaluate the investment. 1) Return on Investment (ROI), calculated as (Total Benefits - Total Costs) / Total Costs * 100%. 2) Net Present Value (NPV), calculated using the formula Σ [ (Cash Flow_t) / (1 + r)^t ] - Initial Investment, which accounts for the time value of money using a specified discount rate (r). 3) Payback Period, calculated as Initial Investment / Annual Net Cash Inflow, which determines how long it takes for the investment to generate enough cash flow to cover its initial cost. General benchmarks suggest a payback period of 12-18 months for a typical AI pilot and median returns of around 10% for full AI investments, though this can be higher in financial services.
roi_model_and_sensitivity_analysis.sensitivity_analysis_summary: A sensitivity analysis is performed to understand how the final ROI or NPV is affected by changes in the most critical input variables. This analysis identifies which assumptions have the most significant impact on the outcome. For example, it would show how a 10% change in 'user adoption rate' or 'time saved per user' alters the projected ROI. The results are often visualized using a tornado chart, which ranks the variables from most to least impactful. This helps the buying committee understand the key drivers of value and the most significant risks to the business case, allowing them to focus on managing the variables that matter most to ensure a successful financial outcome.

competitive_alternatives_and_build_vs_bu.competitive_landscape_summary: The competitive landscape for Hebbia's high-stakes reasoning capabilities at Susquehanna International Group (SIG) is multifaceted, encompassing several distinct categories of tools. These include: 1) Generic Large Language Model (LLM) Chat Interfaces such as ChatGPT Enterprise and Claude for Enterprise, which offer powerful foundational models but often lack the specific guardrails for verifiability and deep synthesis required in finance. 2) Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) and Market Intelligence Platforms, which are closer competitors. This category includes AlphaSense, which offers a vast proprietary library of external content, and Glean, which focuses on internal enterprise search. Other players like Blueflame specialize in the alternative investments vertical. 3) Knowledge Management Systems like Guru, Confluence, and Notion, which are primarily designed for creating centralized internal wikis and process libraries rather than deep analytical reasoning. 4) Specialized Legal AI tools such as Kira Systems and Harvey, which are pre-trained for specific legal clause identification and contract review but lack the flexible, multi-domain reasoning framework of Hebbia. 5) Document AI Solutions like Docsumo and Amazon Textract, which excel at structured data extraction and OCR but are not designed for complex, multi-document synthesis. Finally, the most significant alternative is the option for SIG to pursue an internal build of a custom RAG solution.
competitive_alternatives_and_build_vs_bu.head_to_head_analysis:
When compared against key alternatives, Hebbia demonstrates distinct advantages for SIG's high-stakes, multi-document reasoning workflows. 

- **vs. Generic LLMs (ChatGPT, Claude):** Hebbia's primary differentiator is its 'citation-first' principle and verifiable fact layer. While generic LLMs produce uncited prose, Hebbia provides structured, tabular outputs where every data point is hyperlinked back to its precise source document. This traceability is critical for auditability and defensibility in financial and legal contexts, mitigating the risk of hallucinations. Hebbia's agentic orchestration (ISD architecture) also allows it to process full documents and synthesize across thousands of sources, overcoming the context window limitations of standard RAG systems built on generic LLMs, achieving 92% accuracy on complex financial benchmarks compared to 68% for out-of-the-box RAG.

- **vs. RAG/Market Intelligence Platforms (AlphaSense, Glean):** Against AlphaSense, Hebbia's strength lies in its ability to reason over a user's private, uploaded data. While AlphaSense provides a vast external content library, Hebbia acts as a powerful reasoning engine for SIG's proprietary internal information (memos, research, legal documents). Compared to Glean, which is an enterprise search tool for finding documents, Hebbia focuses on synthesizing net-new insights from a curated set of documents for intensive, project-based analysis, rather than just retrieving existing information.

- **vs. Specialized Legal AI (Kira, Harvey):** Hebbia offers greater flexibility. Tools like Kira are pre-trained to find specific legal clauses, whereas Hebbia's framework allows users to teach it unique analytical workflows across any task or document type, financial or legal. Compared to Harvey, Hebbia's internal processing is more transparent, allowing users to 'see the work' and trace every AI action, reducing the need for extensive human re-verification.

- **Security and Governance:** Hebbia's enterprise-grade security posture (SOC 2 Type I/II, GDPR readiness, encryption) and its strict policy of never training on customer data provide a higher level of assurance for handling sensitive information like MNPI compared to more general-purpose tools or internal builds that would need to establish these controls from scratch.
competitive_alternatives_and_build_vs_bu.build_vs_buy_analysis:
A detailed analysis of the 'build vs. buy' decision for a sophisticated RAG and multi-document reasoning platform reveals significant costs, timelines, and risks associated with an internal build for SIG. 

**Team Composition & Staffing:** An internal build would require a dedicated team of 6-10 full-time equivalents (FTEs), including 2-3 ML Engineers specializing in NLP/RAG, 1-2 Data Engineers, 1-2 Infrastructure/DevOps Engineers, a Security/Compliance Engineer, and Product/Developer support. 

**Estimated Total Cost of Ownership (TCO):** Assuming a fully loaded cost of $250k-$350k per FTE, the annual staffing costs alone would range from $1.5M to $3.5M. Additional annual costs for infrastructure (cloud GPU/CPU, vector DBs), LLM APIs, and ongoing maintenance would add another $1.1M to $4.5M. This brings the estimated TCO for an internal build to $2.6M - $8M in the first year and a total of $7.8M - $24M over three years. 

**Timeline:** The timeline to develop a robust internal solution is substantial. An MVP (Minimum Viable Product) would likely take 6-12 months, with a fully mature, production-grade system requiring 12-24 months of development. This contrasts with Hebbia's claim of being operational 'from day one'.

**Risks and Opportunity Cost:** The internal build path carries significant risks, including the high initial investment, long time-to-value, and the challenge of recruiting and retaining specialized AI/ML talent. The complexity of managing a full RAG stack, including hallucination mitigation and a verifiable citation layer, is non-trivial. Most importantly, pursuing an internal build would divert SIG's elite engineering and quantitative resources away from their core competency: developing proprietary trading strategies. This opportunity cost—the value of the trading innovations not pursued—is a critical factor that strongly favors a 'buy' decision for a specialized, enterprise-ready platform like Hebbia.

risks_mitigations_and_controls.risk_description: The risk involves the potential exposure of highly sensitive and valuable information, such as proprietary trading strategies, quantitative models, research data, or Material Non-Public Information (MNPI), through the use of a third-party AI platform. Unauthorized access, data leakage, or misuse of this intellectual property could lead to significant financial losses and erosion of competitive advantage.
risks_mitigations_and_controls.mitigation_strategy: The proposed mitigation strategy is to engage with a vendor that demonstrates a robust, verifiable security posture and contractually commits to stringent data protection standards. This involves implementing a multi-layered approach that combines technical controls, legal agreements, and operational policies to safeguard sensitive data throughout its lifecycle on the platform.
risks_mitigations_and_controls.control_measures: Specific controls to manage this risk include: 1) **Vendor Certification and Compliance:** Verifying that the vendor (Hebbia) holds key security certifications such as SOC 2 Type I and Type II and is compliant with relevant data protection regulations like GDPR. 2) **Data Encryption:** Ensuring all data is encrypted both at rest using strong algorithms like AES 256 and in transit using protocols like TLS 1.3. 3) **Contractual Prohibitions:** Executing a Data Processing Addendum (DPA) and Master Service Agreement (MSA) that explicitly prohibits the vendor from using any input data for model training, reverse-engineering IP, or any purpose other than providing the service to the client. Hebbia's explicit policy of 'never training on user data' is a critical control. 4) **Access Controls:** Implementing robust identity and access management, including Single Sign-On (SSO) integration and granular Role-Based Access Controls (RBAC), to enforce the principle of least privilege. 5) **Audit Trails:** Maintaining comprehensive and immutable logs of all data access and user activities for monitoring and forensic purposes.

procurement_readiness_checklist.security_and_compliance_documentation: A comprehensive list of security and compliance artifacts must be requested and reviewed. This includes: 1) Hebbia's complete SOC 2 Type I and Type II audit reports. 2) The most recent third-party penetration test reports and summaries of findings. 3) Evidence of ISO 27001 certification. 4) Formal statements and certifications regarding compliance with GDPR and the forthcoming CCPA. 5) Detailed technical documentation outlining encryption standards for data at rest (AES 256) and in transit (TLS 1.3), key management practices, and data handling policies.
procurement_readiness_checklist.contractual_and_legal_terms: The Data Processing Addendum (DPA) and Master Service Agreement (MSA) must address several key terms to protect SIG. These include: 1) **Transparent Pricing:** A clear, scalable, and predictable pricing model with no hidden fees. 2) **Service Level Agreements (SLAs):** Defined SLAs for system uptime, performance (e.g., query latency), and support response times. 3) **Data Ownership and Usage:** Clauses that explicitly state SIG retains full ownership of its data and the outputs generated. The agreement must unequivocally prohibit Hebbia from using any client data for model training, reverse-engineering, or any other purpose. 4) **Confidentiality and IP:** Strong confidentiality clauses to protect SIG's intellectual property. 5) **Liability and Risk Allocation:** Clearly defined liability limits and risk allocation between SIG and Hebbia. 6) **Data Retention and Deletion:** Specific terms governing data retention periods and secure data deletion procedures upon contract termination.
procurement_readiness_checklist.technical_and_deployment_requirements: A technical checklist must be completed prior to procurement. This involves: 1) **Data Flow Diagrams:** Creating and approving detailed diagrams illustrating how data will flow from SIG's internal systems (e.g., SharePoint, email archives, DMS) to the Hebbia platform and back. 2) **Deployment Model Selection:** A formal decision on the deployment model. While Hebbia offers a SaaS solution, a Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) or private cloud deployment within SIG's own cloud tenancy (e.g., Azure) is likely the most appropriate choice to ensure data control and security, balancing compliance with innovation. 3) **Integration Plan:** A plan for integrating Hebbia with SIG's identity provider (e.g., Okta, Azure AD) for Single Sign-On (SSO) and with key data repositories via APIs and connectors. 4) **Data Policies:** Finalizing internal policies for data classification, retention, and usage within the Hebbia environment.
procurement_readiness_checklist.acceptance_and_success_criteria: Formal acceptance of the solution must be tied to predefined success criteria demonstrated during a 6-8 week pilot program. These criteria should be quantitative and directly linked to the business case. Key metrics include: 1) **Efficiency Gains:** A targeted reduction of over 25% in time and resources required for the specific pilot use cases (e.g., document review cycle time). 2) **Return on Investment (ROI):** A model projection indicating a potential ROI exceeding 250%, with a time-to-value of under 9 months. 3) **User Adoption and Satisfaction:** A high adoption rate among the pilot user cohort (e.g., >80% active use) and positive qualitative feedback. 4) **Model Performance:** Verifiable metrics on model accuracy, precision, and a near-zero rate of un-cited 'hallucinated' answers on pilot datasets. 5) **Auditability:** Successful demonstration of the platform's ability to provide a clear, traceable audit trail for all AI actions and data access.

conclusion_and_next_steps.summary_of_value_proposition: Hebbia offers Susquehanna International Group a strategic partnership to fundamentally enhance its operating leverage and create new growth capacity. By deploying our enterprise-grade AI reasoning platform, SIG can transform its vast and complex data landscape from a source of analytical overhead into a source of compounding competitive advantage. We provide the means to accelerate time-to-conviction, scale expert analysis, and improve decision quality, all within a secure, auditable, and compliant framework that respects SIG's stringent operational and regulatory requirements. This partnership is not merely about adopting a new tool, but about systematically upgrading the core workflows that drive SIG's market leadership.
conclusion_and_next_steps.recommended_next_steps:
To move forward, we propose the following clear and collaborative next steps:

1.  **Schedule a Deep-Dive Demonstration (1-2 weeks):** We recommend a 90-minute interactive session with SIG's key stakeholders from trading, quant research, risk, legal, and technology. This session will be tailored to the specific use cases outlined in this proposal, allowing for detailed questions and a live demonstration of Hebbia's capabilities on relevant document types.

2.  **Co-Design the Pilot Program (Week 3):** Following the demonstration, we propose a half-day workshop to collaboratively define the scope, objectives, user group, and success metrics for the 6-8 week pilot program. This will ensure the pilot is precisely aligned with SIG's strategic priorities and provides unambiguous validation of the platform's value.

3.  **Initiate Procurement and Security Review (Week 4):** In parallel, we will provide our complete procurement readiness package, including our SOC 2 Type II report, security architecture documentation, and standard Master Service Agreement (MSA) and Data Processing Addendum (DPA) for review by SIG's legal, compliance, and procurement teams.
